s2.title: What is it?
s2.p: Xalan is an XSLT processor for transforming XML documents into HTML, text, or other XML document types. It implements the W3C Recommendations for XSL Transformations (XSLT) and the XML Path Language (XPath). It can be used from the command line, in an applet or a servlet, or as a module in other program.

s2.title: I've heard of &xslt4j;, but what is version 2?
s2.p: &xslt4j; version 2 recasts Xalan as an implementation of the TRaX (Transformation API for XML) interfaces, part of the . TRaX provides a modular framework and a standard API for performing XML transformations, and it utilizes system properties to determine which Transformer and which XML parser to use.
&xslt4j; version 2 also builds on , , and the XML parser API in .
For more information, see What's new in &xslt4j2;.
s2.note: &xslt4j; version 1 is no longer supported and no longer available from xml.apache.org.

s2.title: How about this release?
s2.p: Following a series of Developer releases, &xslt4j-current; represents a stable, production-quality release with the DTM (Document Table Model). &xslt4j; uses the DTM to represent the XML source document to be transformed.

Starting with 2.2.D12, we have reduced xalan.jar to just include the &xslt4j; implementation, placing the SAX, DOM, and JAVAX interfaces in xml-apis.jar. These interfaces are shared by a number of tools (&xslt4j;, &xml4j;, etc.), so placing them in a separate JAR simplifies coordination and reduces risk of duplication. Be sure to put both JAR files on your classpath!

s2.title: Where do I get Xerces?
s2.p: The Xalan download includes xerces.jar from &xml4j-used;. This is all you need to run Xalan with the Xerces XML parser. You can, however, download the complete Xerces distribution from the . If you are interested in testing or prototyping &xml4j2;, you can run &xslt4j-current; with &xml4j; 2.0.0.beta3; be sure the use the JAVAX interfaces, not the &xml4j; 1 compatibility layer, which does not work with &xml4j; 2.0.0.beta3.
s2.note: If you plan to use a different XML parser, see Plugging in a Transformer and XML parser.

s2.title: What else do I need?
s2.p: You need the Java Development Kit or Java Runtime 1.1.8, 1.2.2, or 1.3, which you can obtain from ibm.com/java/jdk/ or java.sun.com.

s2.p: For more information, go to Xalan Overview and Getting Started. All of the Xalan documentation on this website is included in the Xalan download, as are a number of Samples to help you start using &xslt4j2; to transform XML documents.
